articles.headline: Solvency, Lost in the Fog at the Fed
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is bound by tradition and law to make emergency loans only to solvent institutions. So why did its top officials save Bear Stearns and A.I.G., but not Lehman Brothers?
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is bound by tradition and law to make emergency loans only to solvent institutions. So why did its top officials save Bear Stearns and A.I.G., but not Lehman Brothers?
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to the Federal Reserve’s emergency lending powers, the crucial word is “solvent.” That’s because both by tradition and, since the passage of the Dodd-Frank Act, by law, the Fed can use its emergency powers to make loans only to a solvent institution.

articles.headline: Dependent Care Accounts, Hamstrung by Limits, Are Still Worth Exploring
articles.snippet: The $5,000 set-aside can be used for some babysitting, after-school programs and even summer day camp. The cap hasn’t increased since 1986, however.
articles.abstract: The $5,000 set-aside can be used for some babysitting, after-school programs and even summer day camp. The cap hasn’t increased since 1986, however.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you work for an employer with a standard slate of benefits, perhaps you got the note last week. In 2015, you can put an extra $50 away in your health care flexible spending account on top of the $2,500 you could deposit this year. Every bit of tax savings counts, right?

articles.headline: Justices to Hear New Challenge to Health Law
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court will consider whether the Affordable Care Act allows tax subsidies in those states that did not set up exchanges for people to select their health insurance.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court will consider whether the Affordable Care Act allows tax subsidies in those states that did not set up exchanges for people to select their health insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to hear a new challenge to the Affordable Care Act, potentially imperiling President Obama’s signature legislative achievement two years after it survived a different Supreme Court challenge by a single vote.

articles.headline: U.S.D.A. Approves Modified Potato. Next Up: French Fry Fans.
articles.snippet: The so-called Innate potato, which produces less of a cancer-causing chemical when it is fried, was developed by a major McDonald’s supplier.
articles.abstract: The so-called Innate potato, which produces less of a cancer-causing chemical when it is fried, was developed by a major McDonald’s supplier.
articles.lead_paragraph: A potato genetically engineered to reduce the amounts of a potentially harmful ingredient in French fries and potato chips has been approved for commercial planting, the Department of Agriculture announced on Friday.

articles.headline: Senators Seek Inquiry of Takata Airbag Accusations
articles.snippet: The senators were responding to a New York Times article quoting former employees of the company who said Takata discounted airbag safety issues.
articles.abstract: The senators were responding to a New York Times article quoting former employees of the company who said Takata discounted airbag safety issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three senators are calling for a criminal investigation of the airbag maker Takata after two former employees reported that it had carried out tests on airbags over a decade ago and found signs of defects, yet erased computer files containing data and threw away tested airbags.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Aaron M. Kessler

articles.headline: Defying Soviets, Then Pulling Hungary to Putin
articles.snippet: After helping topple communism in Eastern Europe in 1989, Prime Minister Victor Orban of Hungary has come to question Western values.
articles.abstract: After helping topple communism in Eastern Europe in 1989, Prime Minister Victor Orban of Hungary has come to question Western values.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — A quarter-century ago, as Hungary helped ignite the events that would lead to the collapse of communism, the ferment produced a new political star.
articles.byline: By Rick Lyman and Alison Smale

articles.headline: Obama to Send 1,500 More Troops to Assist Iraq
articles.snippet: The deployment will double the number of Americans meant to train and advise Iraqi and Kurdish forces as they plan a major offensive against Islamic State fighters who have poured into Iraq from Syria.
articles.abstract: The deployment will double the number of Americans meant to train and advise Iraqi and Kurdish forces as they plan a major offensive against Islamic State fighters who have poured into Iraq from Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has authorized the deployment of an additional 1,500 American troops to Iraq in the coming months, doubling the number of Americans meant to train and advise Iraqi and Kurdish forces.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Prominent Editor’s Exit Is Setback for Amazon Publishing Unit
articles.snippet: Ed Park, a novelist who shaped Amazon’s sole literary fiction imprint with his taste and connections, is leaving, raising questions about the program’s future.
articles.abstract: Ed Park, a novelist who shaped Amazon’s sole literary fiction imprint with his taste and connections, is leaving, raising questions about the program’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Amazon hired the novelist Ed Park as a senior editor in its New York publishing office in 2011, it seemed an unlikely match. Mr. Park — a member of New York’s literary elite who had worked for the Poetry Foundation, co-founded a literary magazine and edited The Village Voice’s literary supplement — seemed ill suited to Amazon’s algorithm-driven business.

articles.headline: Finding $816 Million, and Fast, to Save Detroit
articles.snippet: At the center of Detroit’s swift exit from the nation’s largest-ever municipal bankruptcy is an improbable arrangement hashed out in many months of behind-the-scenes negotiations.
articles.abstract: At the center of Detroit’s swift exit from the nation’s largest-ever municipal bankruptcy is an improbable arrangement hashed out in many months of behind-the-scenes negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Late one afternoon last November, leaders of some of the nation’s top foundations were invited into a private meeting in a courthouse conference room here as Judge Gerald E. Rosen, the appointed mediator in this city’s federal bankruptcy case, made an unheard-of request.

articles.headline: Wearing Your Failures on Your Sleeve
articles.snippet: In entrepreneurial circles, a start-up flop is now something to analyze and proclaim, not hide.
articles.abstract: In entrepreneurial circles, a start-up flop is now something to analyze and proclaim, not hide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Cassandra Phillipps founded FailCon, a one-day conference in San Francisco celebrating failure. Discouraged by a growing chorus of start-up founders promoting their triumphs throughout Silicon Valley, and nervous about her own prospects as an entrepreneur, she craved the stories of people who had flopped.

articles.headline: Kenneth Bae and Matthew Todd Miller, Released by North Korea, Are Back on U.S. Soil
articles.snippet: Mr. Bae and Mr. Miller arrived Saturday night at a base near Tacoma, Wash., after a secret negotiation by the director of national intelligence, James R. Clapper Jr.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bae and Mr. Miller arrived Saturday night at a base near Tacoma, Wash., after a secret negotiation by the director of national intelligence, James R. Clapper Jr.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Korea released two Americans who had been accused of trying to subvert the secretive state, after the director of national intelligence for the United States flew to the country on a secret mission and left on Saturday with the men aboard his aircraft.

articles.headline: A Blank Page in the S.E.C. Rule Book, Four Years Later
articles.snippet: The order in the Dodd-Frank law sounded simple: Write a rule governing clawbacks of executive pay. Yet that rule is still unwritten.
articles.abstract: The order in the Dodd-Frank law sounded simple: Write a rule governing clawbacks of executive pay. Yet that rule is still unwritten.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s something that almost everyone can agree on: Executives should return compensation earned improperly as a result of accounting shenanigans at their companies.

articles.headline: Loretta Lynch, a Nominee for Attorney General, Is Praised for Substance, Not Flash
articles.snippet: Ms. Lynch, the federal prosecutor in Brooklyn nominated to be the nation’s attorney general, is a calm, under-the-radar lawyer who is not afraid to fight hard for her cause, associates say.
articles.abstract: Ms. Lynch, the federal prosecutor in Brooklyn nominated to be the nation’s attorney general, is a calm, under-the-radar lawyer who is not afraid to fight hard for her cause, associates say.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Kenneth P. Thompson was a young federal prosecutor in Brooklyn in the late 1990s, he was assigned to one of the biggest cases the office had ever handled, that of the police officers accused of beating and sodomizing Abner Louima, a Haitian immigrant.

articles.headline: With Fear of Being Sidelined, Tea Party Sees the Republican Rise as New Threat
articles.snippet: As Republicans on Capitol Hill move from being the opposition party to being one that has to show it can govern, a powerful tension is emerging between its establishment and its activist wing.
articles.abstract: As Republicans on Capitol Hill move from being the opposition party to being one that has to show it can govern, a powerful tension is emerging between its establishment and its activist wing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As most Republicans were taking a victory lap the morning after the elections, a group of conservatives huddled anxiously in a conference room not far from Capitol Hill and agreed that now is the time for confrontation, not compromise and conciliation.

articles.headline: Getting Close to Terror, but Not to Stop It
articles.snippet: Despite the C.I.A.'s concerns, a Port Authority officer working with the F.B.I. kept ties to sources inside the Sunni terrorist group Jundallah.
articles.abstract: Despite the C.I.A.'s concerns, a Port Authority officer working with the F.B.I. kept ties to sources inside the Sunni terrorist group Jundallah.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a car bombing in southeastern Iran killed 11 Revolutionary Guard members in 2007, a C.I.A. officer noticed something surprising in the agency’s files: an intelligence report, filed ahead of the bombing, that had warned that something big was about to happen in Iran.
articles.byline: By James Risen and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Obstacles Limit Targets and Pace of Strikes on ISIS
articles.snippet: Commanders of the American-led air campaign in Iraq and Syria are challenged by spotty intelligence, poor weather and an Iraqi Army that has only begun an offensive against the Islamic State.
articles.abstract: Commanders of the American-led air campaign in Iraq and Syria are challenged by spotty intelligence, poor weather and an Iraqi Army that has only begun an offensive against the Islamic State.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than three months into the American-led air campaign in Iraq and Syria, commanders are challenged by spotty intelligence, poor weather and an Iraqi Army that is only now starting to go on the offensive against the Islamic State, meaning that warplanes are mostly limited to hitting pop-up targets of opportunity.

articles.headline: Communities Fight State Laws That Can Divide Broadband Access
articles.snippet: Small cities are asking the F.C.C. to use its power to override laws in 19 states that forbid municipalities to build or expand broadband networks.
articles.abstract: Small cities are asking the F.C.C. to use its power to override laws in 19 states that forbid municipalities to build or expand broadband networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILSON, N.C. — Jason Bissette could throw a sweet potato from his office here in eastern North Carolina, where he and his family oversee nearly 3,000 acres, to their newest barn.

articles.headline: Ebola’s Mystery: One Boy Lives, Another Dies
articles.snippet: Over and over, doctors have been confounded by the divergent paths of Ebola patients whose cases appeared similar at first.
articles.abstract: Over and over, doctors have been confounded by the divergent paths of Ebola patients whose cases appeared similar at first.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUAKOKO, Liberia — Soon after he lost his parents to Ebola, Junior Samuel, 8, slumped in a plastic chair inside a treatment center here, listless, feverish and racked with aches. Within a day, he began bleeding from his gums, a particularly ominous sign.

articles.headline: Chasing Relevancy at Any Cost, Even Free
articles.snippet: When U2 and Apple forcibly gave away the band’s latest album, it was a misstep for a group that has fought to avoid fading into the background of the pop culture landscape.
articles.abstract: When U2 and Apple forcibly gave away the band’s latest album, it was a misstep for a group that has fought to avoid fading into the background of the pop culture landscape.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — It took nearly 30 years for “The Joshua Tree,” the 1987 album that was U2’s breakout ticket to megastardom, to reach 30 million people. “Songs of Innocence,” which was released on Sept. 9 as part of the unveiling of the iPhone 6, pulled that off in three weeks. Bono, the band’s leader, explained as much to the packed audience at the Web Summit here, saying that 100 million people had listened to a song or two and that 30 million people had listened to the whole album.

articles.headline: On the Hunt for Wall St. Hackers, but Not the Spotlight
articles.snippet: Lawrence Baldwin is one of the more well-known and valuable allies of financial institutions in their fight against online crime, but the nature of his work means he keeps a very low profile.
articles.abstract: Lawrence Baldwin is one of the more well-known and valuable allies of financial institutions in their fight against online crime, but the nature of his work means he keeps a very low profile.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lawrence Baldwin is a dark hero of the Internet whom you have probably never heard of — and for good reason.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: No Longer Business as Usual in China
articles.snippet: With heads of state and corporate chieftains in Beijing for a major economic summit meeting this week, China’s increasing economic nationalism is expected to be heavily debated.
articles.abstract: With heads of state and corporate chieftains in Beijing for a major economic summit meeting this week, China’s increasing economic nationalism is expected to be heavily debated.
articles.lead_paragraph: China is changing the rule book for business, forcing multinational companies to figure out how to play a new game or risk losing out on the world’s second-largest economy.

articles.headline: Disney Film Boss Alan Horn Finds Success After Ouster by Warner
articles.snippet: As chairman, Alan F. Horn has helped turn Walt Disney Studios into a highly successful movie operation, making a record $1.55 billion profit.
articles.abstract: As chairman, Alan F. Horn has helped turn Walt Disney Studios into a highly successful movie operation, making a record $1.55 billion profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — Alan F. Horn was pushed out by Warner Brothers in 2011 after a celebrated run as its film chief — too old, too out of touch, he was told. Toddle off into a happy retirement, he was advised. Read a book.

articles.headline: Cubicles Rise in a Brave New World of Publishing
articles.snippet: Hachette has abandoned private offices in favor of open-plan cubicles, a trend that has migrated from tech start-ups to even city governments.
articles.abstract: Hachette has abandoned private offices in favor of open-plan cubicles, a trend that has migrated from tech start-ups to even city governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael Pietsch was given his first private office when he became an editor at Charles Scribner’s Sons 30 years ago.

articles.headline: China Builds Financial Ties to Neighbors
articles.snippet: Trade agreements with neighboring nations underscore China’s rising economic clout, as it competes more aggressively for deals and investment dollars.
articles.abstract: Trade agreements with neighboring nations underscore China’s rising economic clout, as it competes more aggressively for deals and investment dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China unveiled a series of measures on Monday aimed at strengthening financial ties with neighboring nations — and potentially weakening Asia’s ties to the United States.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Militant Group in Egypt Vows Loyalty to ISIS
articles.snippet: The affiliation could pull the organization, Ansar Beit al-Maqdis, away from its focus on attacking Egyptian military and security forces and toward the Islamic State’s mass killings of civilians.
articles.abstract: The affiliation could pull the organization, Ansar Beit al-Maqdis, away from its focus on attacking Egyptian military and security forces and toward the Islamic State’s mass killings of civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — They have slaughtered hundreds of Egyptian soldiers and police officers, recruited experienced fighters and staged increasingly sophisticated raids from the Western desert to the Sinai Peninsula. They have beheaded informants and killed an American in a carjacking, say Western officials familiar with intelligence reports.

articles.headline: Obama Asks F.C.C. to Adopt Tough Net Neutrality Rules
articles.snippet: President Obama’s comments were his most direct effort to keep cable and telephone companies from providing special access to some content providers.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s comments were his most direct effort to keep cable and telephone companies from providing special access to some content providers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his most direct effort yet to influence the debate about the Internet’s future, President Obama said on Monday that a free and open Internet was as critical to Americans’ lives as electricity and telephone service and should be regulated like those utilities to protect consumers.
